title: 如果你有時間寫一篇部落格文章，主題會關於什麼？
To make hard questions easier to ask you can preface with one of these two:
Can I ask you a personal question?
I learned a really great question to ask people today, but it’s a really hard question to ask. They'll ask, what’s the question?
Be okay with the silence as the person thinks of their answer.
The energy you give off as you are asking is important. Show that you are calm, friendly, and very genuinely interested in what the person has to say.

When talking with someone and want to move the conversation past small talk quickly, I’ll often ask them if they want to play The Question Game. The only rule is that we ask questions back and forth and take turns answering. They’ll start with safe questions. You start with medium questions, but escalate pretty quickly. As soon as you both answer one high vulnerability question, your relationship instantly goes to a whole new level.
Some Tips

“A good question is like the one Albert Einstein asked himself as a small boy — ‘What would you see if you were traveling on a beam of light?’ That question launched the theory of relativity, E=MC2, and the atomic age’.
i
A good question question is not concerned with a correct answer.
i
A good question cannot be answered immediately.
i
A good question challenges existing answers.
i
A good question creates new territory of thinking.
i
A good question is one that generates many other good questions.
i
A good question may be the last job a machine will learn to do.
i
A good question is what humans are for.”
i
What makes a good question?

For something you think you can only achieve in 2-5-10 or more years: if I only had 6 months to achieve this, what would I have to do?
Is it true? Can you be absolutely sure it's true? How do you react when you think that thought? Who would you be without that thought?
From Loving What Is: Four Questions that can Change Your Life
What’s a life hack you do that very few people know about?
What is something controversial now that you think won’t be in a couple of years?
What are two to three people you think will be super impactful that aren’t yet?
What do you think is the thing holding people back the most?
What is the kindest thing someone has done to you?
What’s the smallest habit you have that makes the biggest difference?
For something challenging/a hardship: How can this be seen as a gift?
For famous, talented people in certain fields
What are the three questions you get asked more often? What are your answers?
What question do you wish people asked you more?
What is the impact you want to have on the world?

Some of my favorite for "experts":
Most useful mental models for your specific industry?
What is some advice you're happy you ignored?
What question do you wish people asked you more?
What do most people get wrong about X industry?
If you could write something in a banner that a huge amount of people would see, what would it be?
Tempting Questions for Self
If I wasn’t thinking about this, would it still be a problem?”
How often do you just complain when you should instead be setting an example?
Is there anyone that's helped you along the way that you haven't thanked enough?
What would you do more of if you didn’t have to worry about being perfect at it?
How many of your problems are due to you answering the wrong questions?
What would you stop doing if you only had a year left to live? What would you start doing if you had 10,000 years to live?
What is one thing you can remove from your life that would improve it?
How many opinions do you accept simply because you fear saying “I don’t know”?
What's something you used to know that would be useful to remember again?
‘What is the most capable version of me that I can imagine?’
‘What would I be like/spend my time doing if all my current major problems had been solved?’
‘What are the things I say I value but don’t act as if I value, and what would my life feel like if I actually acted as if I valued those things?’
‘What am I afraid of doing, and what would my life be like if I wasn’t afraid of doing those things?’
How much of what you care about is based on wanting others to think you care?
If you were 90, how much would you pay to go back to relive the moments you’re living?
What would you do if you had no responsibilities?
Am I excited to be doing what I’m doing or am I in aimless motion?
Are the trade-offs between work and my relationships [or my life buckets] well-balanced?
How can I speed up the process from where I am to where I want to go?
What big opportunities am I not pursuing that I potentially could?
What’s a small thing that will produce a disproportionate impact?
What could probabilistically go wrong in the next 6 months of my life?
When I had the opportunity, did I choose courage over comfort?
How long will you put off what you are capable of doing just to continue what you are comfortable doing?
How long will you put off what you are capable of doing just to continue what you are comfortable doing?
Good questions to bring out your inner artist out:
b

65 and money: 5 postponed pleasures / adventures

Questions that Pull Out Interesting
What is something you'd want to prove but can't?
What is something you see most people believe but you think is wrong?
What is something you believe that very few people also believe?
What's true but not obvious? As in, what's a robust heuristic not yet a cliche?
What have been the 3 most pivotal moments in your life?
Questions for Junto Intro
Questions for Junto Intro
Questions for refining ideas
But how do you combine the ideas? Are there specific processes you can use? How do you refine ideas? How do you assess ideas?

I like to ask questions to inspire new thoughts. Questions trigger answers. Questions can change the angle at which you’re looking at something — or they can direct your eyes to look at something new.
Some examples I’ve found useful for refining, combining, and assessing ideas include:
Under what circumstances does this apply?
(For hard, long term ideas): how can I do this in 6 months instead of 5 years?
What is something you believe that very few people also believe?
What is something you want to do in your life that less than 2 of your 10 closest friends also want to do?
At the end of your life, as you look back, would you regret this?
What’s the worst thing that could happen?
What is the expected outcome? Weighted with probabilities and assessing the values.
How can you create a third option?
What would this look like in 5-10 years?
What will likely change in 10 years?
What will not change in 10 years?
Why does this matter? Why do you want to do it?
Is there a harder way of doing it? Is there an easier way? Is there a faster or cheaper way?
Is this in alignment with your values? With your life purpose?
Are you thinking long term?
What is some possible emergent behavior that might arise?
What are the psychological implications? Economical, brand, philosophical, moral implications.
Have you taken enough time to think about this?
Do you even need more time?
What is something people would be scared of?
How can you add an element of surprise / delight / elegance / legitimacy, etc. ?
What feeling do you want to evoke?
What does this stand for? Does it represent something?
What are the second and third order implications?
How can this be improved?
Brainstorm what would be a six-star experience. A 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 star experience? Come up with something for each one.
What can you compromise? What can’t be compromised?
What are WOW features? What are absolutely essential features? What are nice to haves?
Can you apply lessons from other fields to this?
What mental models is this based on?
What other mental models might be useful for this?
Has someone else done or tried this? How did they do it? What can you learn from them?
What is something that’s unlikely anyone has tried?
Is this a defensive or an attacking strategy? Is it to not-to-lose or to win?
What can you experiment with?
What tools can you use? What tools can you create?
How can other people help you?
What constraints do you have and how can you use them to your advantage? What can you innovate with the constraints?
Generating Thiel Answers
b
a
https://www.syscreativity.com/all_posts.html

The Thiel Question — what is a truth very few people agree with you on — is a fantastic descriptor of contrarian truth, and a terrible generator. Here are some generators for the next time Thiel appears out of nowhere to stump you:
What about the world is broken that no one knows is broken?
What do most people get wrong about everything?
What massive societal change is coming that no one knows is coming?
What massive technological change is coming that no one knows is coming?
What has been fundamentally misunderstood?
What truths are too terrifying for us to admit?
What do you do that you wish everyone did?
What supposedly implausible scenarios are actually possible, or fairly likely?
What dystopian future must actually be guarded against?
What halcyon future may be possible to build?
Lifechange Leading Questions
b
a
https://www.syscreativity.com/all_posts.html
What we call learning is a pale imitation of generation. Knowing a thing is different from being able to do the thing — though the best way to know a thing is often to do it.

Creativity is best applied to relevant problems in your life. One way to bring these to mind, and which can later operate as raw material to run systematizing creativity on, is to ask leading questions. Use all, some, or none:
What do you want to change in life?
What do you wish was different in your life?
What do you always wish you could do?
What do you think you could never do, but would want to?
What would your friends tell you to do?
What scares you?
What frustrates you?
What confuses you?
What interests you?
What questions are you grappling with right now?
What do most people get wrong?
What do most people get wrong about everything?
What does your personal hell look like?
What does your personal heaven look like?
If you had a week to change you life before it became set in stone, what would you do? What would you focus on?
If you had 10 years to get your life in order, what would you do?
If you have 10 assistants, what would you have them do for you?
If you could change 1 thing about your life, what would it be?
If you could only improve your life an hour a day, what would you do?
What do you wish everyone did?
What is the truth you are too scared to admit?
What is the truth you wish you had courage to admit?
If you could understand 1 thing, what would it be
What are the 10 academic fields you want to understand
What are the tools or technologies you use to improve your life, why do you do so? What are you trying to solve?
What do your friends say about your desires?
What did you get most mad at yourself this week about? This quarter? The last 10 years?
What were you most proud of this week? This quarter? The last 10 years?
If systematizing creativity went better than your wildest expectations, what happened? What did you focus on?
Create a prompt list of words, concepts, domains, people and ask is there anything you want to adopt, think about, become, take, steal, or use?
Compounding Knowledge Questions
Will you care about what your reading in a month? In a year? In five years?
Are you focused enough on the same thing to build cumulative knowledge or are you too spread out?
What do you spend time on that’s likely to change in the next few years? What’s not likely to change?
What are you interested in and what are you working on?
What have you done so far that shows your potential for greatness, adjusted for whatever life circumstances you were born into?
In a best-case scenario, what do you want your obituary to say?
